document_data.name: A Merchant's Tale
document_data.author: [[Jarn Tiir]]
document_data.mainbody:
'''''A Merchant's Tale''''' was a [[book]] written by [[Jarn Tiir]] of [[Lantan]] in the late 13{{th}} century [[DR]].

{{quote|''Always we hurry through our lives, we who travel. Only folk tied to the land wait for danger to come to them. All others blunder ever onward, [[sword]]s at the ready, through many meetingsâ€“and each may be the last, for in the wilds only the [[dragon]] waits for his meals to walk into him. The [[wolf]], the [[orc]], the [[gorgon]] hunt and smile much when they meet dinner. What is more dangerous even than these? Why, any [[human|man]] you meet.''|Excerpt from ''A Merchant's Tale''}}
document_data.History: ''A Merchant's Tale'' was a collection of life lessons and musings published in the {{YearlinkName|1287}}. The work shared some insights into the nature of those who lived to travel and the lesson that a human was more dangerous than any monster waiting in the wild.{{Cite web/The Candlekeep Collection}}
